stem: A 72-year-old male is 8 hours post-inguinal hernia repair. Based on the documentation in the I&O & Bladder Surveillance flowsheet, what is the most appropriate nursing intervention?

options.text: Perform a straight catheterization as per standing orders.
Wait 2 more hours to allow the anesthesia to fully wear off.
Encourage the client to stand at the bedside to void.
Administer an IV fluid bolus to stimulate kidney function.

rationale.correct: The client is experiencing acute urinary retention (a1). The intake/output log shows significant fluid intake (over 1,300 mL) with only 30 mL of total output (dribbling), which is a classic sign of retention/overflow. A bladder scan showing 780 mL confirms that the bladder is full but cannot empty. Per the provider orders (400 mL threshold), straight catheterization is the immediate priority to relieve pressure and prevent bladder distention damage.
clinicalPearls: Voiding < 30 mL/hr or only 'dribbling' in a patient with high intake is 'Urinary Retention' until proven otherwise.
Post-operative urinary retention (POUR) is common due to anesthesia, opioids, and manipulation (especially in pelvic/hernia surgeries).
Always bladder scan BEFORE catheterizing to confirm the problem is the bladder (retention) rather than the kidneys (anuria).

questionTrap.trap: Thinking standing at the bedside (a3) is the first action when the bladder is already at 780 mL.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While mobility helps *prevent* retention, once the bladder is at 780 mL (nearly double the safe limit), the patient is in acute distress and needs mechanical relief (catheter) immediately.

mnemonic.title: Scan & Pan
mnemonic.expansion: Scan it (Bladder scan). Plan it (Cath if > 400). Pan it (Check the urine color).

1. Advance diet as tolerated.
